I'm making some good progress lately in my glossing of the documents, I'm getting to the point where I can usually read the majority of any given sentence, but there are of course always words I'm not familiar with and sometimes my consultant isn't either.
(1) kunkoo vs tono kaa vs ta kaa = "to look like" - "to be like/similar to"?
The example in the the document is:
" kiti yo'o ta kunkoo tina ni kunkoo ti , tia luu so ka ti "
>How would you translate this? This animal looks like a dog, but it is much smaller.
>Why the second use of 'kunkoo' with no other thing to compare the animal to?
>What is the " ni " meaning here" " pues "
>What is the "so" my speaker tends to group it with other things around it when he glosses them but (1.5)Sometimes it means completely or it functions as an intensifier.
Other sentences have meaning similar to "to look like"
"Yutu yo'o tsa'i kui'i luu ntikuaan, cha kai tono manzana luu cha iya ña" "this tree produces small yellow fruit, and it looks like a small apple and it is sour" Ok.

(2) Sentence translation/spelling check
The following sentence from the "To'lo ña ma nikuu ka kana" (L106) my speaker helped a little but doesn't know "vari" in this context.
"Tsa'a ña niku'u ti, vari va'a ka ti kukuu ti nchai" "because that he/it was sick, (vari) bad (=old spelling) topic.mkr he/it would be food" This is what this sentence should say: "Sara saꞌa na nchaꞌa tsi kue toꞌlo tsi kue chata ña kuntasi ti, tsaꞌa ña nikuꞌu ti." "E hicieron una salsa (mole) con los gallos y las gallinas que lo rechazaban, por qué (por lo que) se había enfermado." Mixtec people would translate the last clause like, "por lo que se había enfermado." This phrase, "tsaꞌa ña" por lo que it is like por qué (because), but here "tsaꞌa ña" (which is different from "tsaꞌa ñaa" por eso, thatꞌs why) refers back to the event when the hens and roosters rejected the ill rooster. I think that "por lo que" is more or less the equivalent in English, because of.
